title: Birth in Calamba, Laguna
summary: José Protasio Mercado Rizal y Alonso Realonda is born in Calamba to Francisco Mercado and Teodora Alonso, the seventh of eleven children.

title: Graduates from Ateneo Municipal de Manila
summary: Rizal completes his Bachelor of Arts with highest honors at Ateneo, where he is mentored by Jesuit educators who sharpen his writing and artistic skills.

title: Begins Medical Studies at the University of Santo Tomas
summary: Rizal enrolls in philosophy and medicine but faces discrimination, prompting his decision to pursue further studies in Europe.

title: Departs for Europe
summary: With the blessing of his elder brother Paciano, Rizal secretly sails for Spain to continue his studies and engage with reformist circles.

title: Publishes Noli Me Tángere
summary: Rizal's first novel, printed in Berlin, critiques colonial abuses and sparks debate among Filipino expatriates and Spanish officials.

title: Returns to the Philippines
summary: Rizal comes home to Calamba, where the success of Noli Me Tángere leads to surveillance by colonial authorities.

title: Founds Indios Bravos in Paris
summary: Together with fellow ilustrados, Rizal organizes a society promoting Filipino excellence and solidarity across Europe.

title: Releases El Filibusterismo
summary: Printed in Ghent, Rizal's second novel offers a darker critique of colonial rule and advocates for socio-political reforms.

title: Exile in Dapitan
summary: Arrested upon his return, Rizal is exiled to Dapitan in Mindanao, where he runs a school, clinic, and civic projects.

title: Marries Josephine Bracken
summary: In Dapitan, Rizal and Josephine Bracken exchange vows before his departure to serve as a military doctor in Cuba.

title: Military Trial in Manila
summary: Rizal is tried and convicted of rebellion, sedition, and conspiracy based on his alleged ties to the Katipunan uprising.

title: Martyrdom at Bagumbayan
summary: Rizal is executed by firing squad at Bagumbayan (Luneta), leaving a final poem, Mi Último Adiós, and inspiring the Philippine Revolution.
